data.markdown:
Find “rhodo.art.q20.int.PE.reads” and add this set of paired-end reads to your Narrative by mousing over it and clicking the Add button that appears at its left. Exit the Data Browser by clicking either the Close button at the bottom right of the browser window or the arrow at the top of the Data Panel. (Note that you also can close the Data Browser by clicking anywhere in the main Narrative panel in the center.) ![](http://kbase.us/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/AssembleAnnotate10.png) After a moment your Data Panel will update to show the dataset that you just added. Don’t be concerned that there is only one data object for the paired-end reads. In KBase, the two original paired-end read files get combined into a single data object.

Suggested Replacements:

  2. build_genome_set_from_tree_generic
    • Build Genome Set From Tree
## Step 2. Add and run the app Now that you have your input data, you can add the Assemble and Annotate Microbial Genome app to your Narrative. Take a closer look at the Apps & Methods Panel directly below your data. In KBase, apps and methods are the same thing except that an app consists of more than one method. In this case, we are using a two-step app. You can search for apps or methods using the search box at the top of the Apps & Methods Panel or just scroll until you find the one you want. Find the Assemble and Annotate Microbial Genome app and click on its name (or icon) to add it as a new cell in the main Narrative panel.

Find “rhodo.art.q20.int.PE.reads” and add this set of paired-end reads to your Narrative by mousing over it and clicking the Add button that appears at its left. Exit the Data Browser by clicking either the Close button at the bottom right of the browser window or the arrow at the top of the Data Panel. (Note that you also can close the Data Browser by clicking anywhere in the main Narrative panel in the center.) ![](http://kbase.us/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/AssembleAnnotate10.png) After a moment your Data Panel will update to show the dataset that you just added. Don’t be concerned that there is only one data object for the paired-end reads. In KBase, the two original paired-end read files get combined into a single data object.

data.markdown: # Notes ## Cell Improvements Cell mechanics are currently a little wonky. - bugs - cell contents shift as they are selected - menu bottom will hide under container bottom if overlap - hard to see cells, since they don't have boundaries - the cell prompt causes the code cells to shift over (it needs a hard width) - todo - icon not displayed for new app cell -- looks like the toolbar and app contents are rendered before the cell is built, so the prompt is not available. - method cell does not start with toolbar area displayed. ## Review of Widgets ### Analyze use the Analayze tab, ensure all buttons work, panels open close ### Analyze > Data ### Analyze > Apps & Methods # Bugs ## Analyze/Data - if data in panel, then delete it, it still appears in the data panel. - also, if add data, the data panel is not updated. - Data Flyout Panel - try to add public data gives error ``` Error: Object kb|g.1427 cannot be accessed: User eapearson may not read workspace KBasePublicGenomesV5 ``` - error is persistent -- even switching data tabs it stays there - even closing and re-opening the data tab, it stays there. - Back to the sidebar data panel, the filter doesn't work very well. It does not always show filtered results, even if it says it has the data, and it does not actually reset to show all when show all is selected. - The big red plus button can obscure functional parts of the last data item. E.g. the ... menu, as well as informational bits (e.g. the metadata that pops up from ...). - on the last data item, when expand the item via the ..., it will open up below the container, so that the container needs to be scrolled up to access it. - Can't drag data item to bottom of narrative - data widgets don't render a loading icon while loading. - drop zone for data widgets is not shown visually, it is a guess as to where it will appear. - Dragged data object goes "under" many elements in the narrative view - sometimes the "drag onto narrative -->" tooltip persists after the item has been left, and sometimes gets in the way. - the links to data items should not be tooltips, it provides no useful information. - clicking the title to place in narrative is not intuitive, i would expect the title to pop up a description or something. A simple arrow on the right hand side would be better. ## Apps & Methods - right side of filter is cut off by the X button - filtering is generall weird and non-intuitive. - no drag/drop, which is weird given that the data objects are draggable. - should show how many items are displayed in the filter (currently only shows how many are NOT displayed!) - an output name may be pre-populated by existing data objects. whether you want to select one or not, one WILL be selected and inserted into the field. ## Narrative Editor / Viewer - vertical scroll when not necessary. - no positive feedback that saving is in progress, subtle message when the save has succeeded. - this comes into play if you want to save and then reload ... reload generates an warning if save has not finished, but it is hard to know when save has finished - save button should be enabled when save is valid (that is, anything changed.) - save message is "checkpoint created 00:00:00" - time is not valid - "checkpoint" does not match "save" nor "version" - the message disappears too quickly - there should be narrative info buttons on the main document view, at least as functional as the ones on the narrative list. perhaps an "info" button which pops up info about this narrative, including metadata, save history/versions, authorship, sharing, etc. - when adding new widgets via the markdown or code round buttons at the bottom right, it is unclear where they are placed. They are not highlighted. - the insert cell above/below menu option in the toolbar is not very useful. It only adds a markdown cell. Perhaps it could be called "add markdown above/below" but that seems to be rather limited utility. ## App Widgets - overall, it looks like there are cases in which the ipython keyboard trapping is not being handled. I added a widget, Assemble and Annotate, could select reads, but not enter output, then when I pressed the "d" key the cell was deleted. - entry into select2 dropdown/entry combo is really weird. The entry area is below the normal input box. - advanced params is weird. - The second column repeats the labels of the first - info tooltips repeat the same thing again - long labels from first column overlap the second, they don't wrap - after inputing paramters, but before running, when saving the narrative, the parameters are not saved ## Markdown Widget - the placeholder text "Type _Markdown_ and LaTeX: $\\alpha^2$" should be present as markdown when double click. - or the placeholder text should be removed, what purpose does it really serve? # Here Bugs This is for recording bugs in new things that I've introduced ## Not working right - markdown cell shows both edit and preview (input and output) when entering edit mode (dblclick) after the cell has been closed and then re-opened. - markdown cells do not get an icon when first opened in a narrative. they do when the markdown cell is added, and they do after it is edited and rendered. this has to do with the icon being shown in the prompt area, which is not in the cell toolbar, and is not necessarily available when the markdown is first rendered, which sends the event to the toolbar, which also must have been rendered. of course, best would be if the entire framework were rendered, and then each widget given the go signal. still, i can surely work aroud this, just haven't done it yet. perhaps will store the title, icon, and other state shared between these cell features in the cell js object properties (right now using the cell node because when I started this it wasn't clear how or if the cell js object was propagated through to the constructors etc.) - run and error icons don't work correctly for app and method cells. - code cells don't collapse or have a title ## Could be better - the insert cell above/below on the gear icon are not all that useful, because only inserts markdown. - collapse all with option + click and/or ctrl + click. Look for best practices for this (e.g. maybe better if there were a button on the notebook toolbar to do this instead. - when saving, the state of the cell should be better preserved. E.g. if a Markdown cell is being edited, it would be best to have it opened as such (and even nice if the cursor were positioned correctly.) ## More Bugs - inserting a new cell does not select the new cell - inserting or moving a cell does not result in activated buttons ## View Mode - should turn off border, celltoolbar, open all cells # Hello, I'm a Markdown Cell

data.markdown:
# Microbial Metabolic Model Reconstruction and Analysis Janaka's version ---- A key scientific objective of KBase’s Microbes team is to reconstruct and predict metabolic and transcriptional regulatory networks to facilitate the manipulation of microbial function (for example, to optimize biofuel products). This tutorial highlights the tools in KBase that support the reconstruction and analysis of genome-scale metabolic models from genome sequence data. > NOTE (to users): This tutorial is read-only. It shows the results of the steps. If you'd like to run the steps yourself--and maybe change some of the parameters or input your own data--you will need to make your own copy of it. Click the blue “Copy Narrative” button at the top right of the screen. This will copy the Narrative that you are currently viewing to your account, and you should see the new copy appear at the top of “My Narratives”. The copy is now yours–-you can open it, run it, edit it, and even share it with others. For more information, please see the [Narrative User Guide](http://kbase.us/narrative-guide/access-and-copy-narratives/). The steps shown in this tutorial are: ## 1. Load a Genome into your Narrative You can upload your own data to KBase to analyze it, but for demonstration purposes in this tutorial, we’ll start by choosing a data object—-a genome—-that's already in KBase and adding it to our Narrative. To add the example genome, first click the Add Data (or red “+”) button in the Data Panel on the left of your screen. (If you don’t see this button, make sure you have the Analyze tab selected.) The Data Browser will slide out, with tabs that show several data sources. Select the Public tab and search for Escherichia coli K12. Find the genome called "Escherichia_coli_K12" and add it to your Narrative by hovering your cursor over it and clicking the Add button that appears at its left. _(I will update this screenshot)_ ![](http://kbase.us/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/AssembleAnnotate10.png) Exit the Data Browser by clicking either the Close button at the bottom right of the browser window or the arrow at the top of the Data Panel. (Note that you also can close the Data Browser by clicking anywhere in the main Narrative panel in the center.) After a moment your Data Panel will update to show the dataset that you just added. ## 2. What's in your Genome object? You can click on the Shewanella_oneidensis_MR-1 genome object in your Data panel to see a genome viewer (see below). If you click on the name of the genome at the top of the viewer (Shewanella_oneidensis_MR-1), a Landing Page (also called Detail Page) for that genome will open in a new browser tab. -- short explantion of each tab (from the genome man page/tutorial) ## 3. Reconstruction of Metabolic Model and Gapfill in Complete Media KBase’s toolkit includes apps and methods for reconstruction, curation, reconciliation, and analysis of metabolic models. This section and the sections that follow explore some of that functionality. # Microbial Metabolic Model Reconstruction and Analysis Janaka's version ---- A key scientific objective of KBase’s Microbes team is to reconstruct and predict metabolic and transcriptional regulatory networks to facilitate the manipulation of microbial function (for example, to optimize biofuel products). This tutorial highlights the tools in KBase that support the reconstruction and analysis of genome-scale metabolic models from genome sequence data. > NOTE (to users): This tutorial is read-only. It shows the results of the steps. If you'd like to run the steps yourself--and maybe change some of the parameters or input your own data--you will need to make your own copy of it. Click the blue “Copy Narrative” button at the top right of the screen. This will copy the Narrative that you are currently viewing to your account, and you should see the new copy appear at the top of “My Narratives”. The copy is now yours–-you can open it, run it, edit it, and even share it with others. For more information, please see the [Narrative User Guide](http://kbase.us/narrative-guide/access-and-copy-narratives/). The steps shown in this tutorial are: ## 1. Load a Genome into your Narrative You can upload your own data to KBase to analyze it, but for demonstration purposes in this tutorial, we’ll start by choosing a data object—-a genome—-that's already in KBase and adding it to our Narrative. To add the example genome, first click the Add Data (or red “+”) button in the Data Panel on the left of your screen. (If you don’t see this button, make sure you have the Analyze tab selected.) The Data Browser will slide out, with tabs that show several data sources. Select the Public tab and search for Escherichia coli K12. Find the genome called "Escherichia_coli_K12" and add it to your Narrative by hovering your cursor over it and clicking the Add button that appears at its left. _(I will update this screenshot)_ ![](http://kbase.us/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/AssembleAnnotate10.png) Exit the Data Browser by clicking either the Close button at the bottom right of the browser window or the arrow at the top of the Data Panel. (Note that you also can close the Data Browser by clicking anywhere in the main Narrative panel in the center.) After a moment your Data Panel will update to show the dataset that you just added. ## 2. What's in your Genome object? You can click on the Shewanella_oneidensis_MR-1 genome object in your Data panel to see a genome viewer (see below). If you click on the name of the genome at the top of the viewer (Shewanella_oneidensis_MR-1), a Landing Page (also called Detail Page) for that genome will open in a new browser tab. -- short explantion of each tab (from the genome man page/tutorial) ## 3. Reconstruction of Metabolic Model and Gapfill in Complete Media KBase’s toolkit includes apps and methods for reconstruction, curation, reconciliation, and analysis of metabolic models. This section and the sections that follow explore some of that functionality. Now that you’ve loaded a genome object into the narrative, you can build an initial draft metabolic model based on the gene annotations in your genome object. Go to the APPS & METHODS panel at the left. (If you don't see it, make sure you're looking at the "Analyze" tab.) In KBase, apps and methods are the same thing except that an app consists of more than one method. You can search for apps or methods using the search box at the top of the Apps & Methods Panel (click the magnifying glass), or just scroll until you find the one you want. Find the "Build Metabolic Model" method and click on its name (or icon) to add it as a new step in your Narrative. Now you need to fill in the fields for the method. Choose the E. coli genome you loaded, and make up a name for the model that will be created. Then click the "Run" button at the bottom of the method cell to start building the model. data.markdown:
# Narrative Sprint - To CI (and Beyond!)

This Narrative document is being used to track my progress with this sprint, and to collect thoughts about improvements and enhancements... # Notes

Blah... bleeh
 # Must Fixes

- ~~Toolbar is not always in selected state when cell select - nail down the cases and fix.~~
  - _okay, one use case is when a cell is deleted, and the previous cell is selected._
  - _Fixed: traced the deletion call from kbase's kbaseNarrativeWorkspace, to notebook.js, which takes care of selecting the appropriate cell through cell.select. So extended that method in custom.js so that we can emit an event 'selected.cell' directly to the cell. This event is already set up to do the right thing._ 
  - _It works, and also allowed the removeal of the same event from kbaseNarrative from within the 'select.Cell' handler. It appears that select.Cell is not always called for cell selection within jupyter, instead the direct select method is used, which does not emit an event_
- main buttons disappear after a while after network connection loss (and failed save... but need more testing)
- weird error message upon save of narrative if no network connection (for local dev install, but simulates workspace loss for a narrative?)

## Navbar
- kernel > About Jupyter does nothing.
- login button does not show gravatar
- login button does not show user's name or username
- login dropdown should disappear if user clicks away; right now it only does so if user clicks again

## Login

Login weirdness:

sign out ends up on 404: http://localhost:8888, without login button

can sign in at http://localhost:8888/narrative/tree, which has the sign in button

after login on the tree page, it is not refreshed

if sign out with data filled in, get "Are you sure you want to leave this page? Unsaved changes will be lost" Even if one selects "Saty on page", the logout event proceeds and the narrative "looks" as before, but ...
- it should not be even visible if the user is logged out (close window, redirect, refresh, anything)
- not just narrative, but menu buttons stay there and initiall "work", but will not actually do what you want them to. E.g. share just hangs; kernel menu still works even without auth

if try to save "Narrative savew failed!" with no message, and just OK button; also hyellow message in narrative shows "You do not have permission to view the narrative with id XXX".

login works, and back to normal.

possible to have jupyter keyboard commands leak through in this case - fresh narrative view, make changes, logout out, click stay on page, try to log back in again -- now keystrokes go to ipython and start doing dark magic to one's narrative, and do not appear in the log in form.



## Markdown
- ~~Markdown cell state gets messed up (input AND output) upon going into edit mode.~~
- ~~double clicking should open up and put into edit mode. right now just puts into edit mode without opening, weird...~~
  - _so now it toggles open if it was closed to start with, does nothing additional with edit mode._
  - _next is to hide the output when going into edit mode. my guess is that the toggling gets reversed with the open/close, and the logic for the editor is to simply toggle the output area -- there is not input/output state stored in cell?_
  - _okay, that is now fixed. It was due to the jquery hide()/show() -- show ends up leaving display="block" on the element, even if it was not set originally. The new method adds display="none" and then removes the display style for showing. Also key to this is the method used by the markdown editor to swap the editor and rendered -- it uses a class on the cell (rendered/unrendered) to control the visilibity of the editor/rendered_
  
- exiting from edit mode is annoying. 
  - When blurring on the markdown edit field, it just closes. This makes sense when clicking to another narrative element (perhaps), but not when just blurring out to another app. If one is writing, and needs to activate other windows, etc. as part of that process, it is plain annoying to have the editor close down, lose cursor position, etc.
  
## Code Cells

- when opening a code cell, the widget area prompt is displayed. This is surely another case of the toggle method employed either being too crude or simply out of sync with the way that the notebook hides/shows code cell elements

## Concurrent Usage

There needs to be a better story for concurrent usage of a narrative. As it is, concurrent saves are allowed, and they do not "overwrite" but just will interleave changes in the versions; it does "appear" that there has been overwriting...
So, perhaps better detection of  # Nice to Have

- nicer save / savepoint feedback
- silly hover paragraph icon for markdown cells -- built into notebook, but why? 
- double click expands closed cells,
- remove extraneous items from kernel menu
- "About this Narrative" button/menu item and pop up dialog (or maybe even a cell?) populated with useful info about the narrative - created, last saved, versions, copies...
- narrative preferences: autosave, mode (basic/advanced), 
- run button in cell toolbar for code, app, method cells.
- help! we need more integrated help. For starters:
  - cell specific help - markdown, code cells
  - data cells should at least have (some of the) tools available in the data panel
  - app and method cells could open up a modal narrative method store
- better messaging experience -
   - consistent location for messages
   - better language
   - longer persistence, or long persistence with ability to close
   - message log (at least for the narrative session) with ability to clear, or expand to get more info or help.
   - this could be on the expanded left nav area
- "reset" or "normalize" for app/method cells. The jupyter markdown styling can interfere with widget styling, which causes otherwise good people to put in place hacks to override. (kb output cell something or other). Rather, the style reset should be at the top level, and any specific styling (for input, output, etc) within an app/method cell should be provided by the widget developer (or perhaps even there the app/method cell should provide this...) # Cool!

- drag and drop cells
- drag and drop apps and methods
- binding of cells to each other (move, d&d, delete, etc.)
- drag and drop code cell and markdown cell 
- basic and advanced mode. Advanced mode would unlock features like code cell icon, kernel menu, and perhaps other ipython stuff
- more metrics: narrative opens, narrative runs, ... # Ideas / Maybe

Move Apps and Methods into own panel, remove Narratives, make a better dashboard, or a slide out panel for narratives. Narratives is not really a useul tool to have within a narrative, compared to the primary tools of the object browser, app & method browser, and jobs. Also, the narrative browser should have more space -- titles often wrap, there should be search.

Move New Narrative to the horizontal menu (does not exist yet) or simply make a navbar button (for copy too)

Remove the annoying circle buttons at the bottom of the narrative. It is weird to have that be the way to add code and markdown cells, yet data viewers and apps/methods are added from the left side.

Remove the big + circle button from data. It is confusing, since there is already a way to pull up the data panel, and gets in the way.

While on the subject of the left area, perhaps there is a better way to provide "tabs". The horizontal space is very limited, and it may that there are more than major functions to expose. 

For example, what about a narrative summary (like or perhaps instead of an info pop-up), or a list of narrative elements with basic information and for navigation, and perhaps simple editing (move, delete cells). Could be useful for long narratives.

Insert raw images into narrative

- ~~Toolbar is not always in selected state when cell select - nail down the cases and fix.~~
  - _okay, one use case is when a cell is deleted, and the previous cell is selected._
  - _Fixed: traced the deletion call from kbase's kbaseNarrativeWorkspace, to notebook.js, which takes care of selecting the appropriate cell through cell.select. So extended that method in custom.js so that we can emit an event 'selected.cell' directly to the cell. This event is already set up to do the right thing._ 
  - _It works, and also allowed the removeal of the same event from kbaseNarrative from within the 'select.Cell' handler. It appears that select.Cell is not always called for cell selection within jupyter, instead the direct select method is used, which does not emit an event_
- main buttons disappear after a while after network connection loss (and failed save... but need more testing)
- weird error message upon save of narrative if no network connection (for local dev install, but simulates workspace loss for a narrative?)

## Navbar
- kernel > About Jupyter does nothing.
- login button does not show gravatar
- login button does not show user's name or username
- login dropdown should disappear if user clicks away; right now it only does so if user clicks again

## Login

Login weirdness:

sign out ends up on 404: http://localhost:8888, without login button

can sign in at http://localhost:8888/narrative/tree, which has the sign in button

after login on the tree page, it is not refreshed

if sign out with data filled in, get "Are you sure you want to leave this page? Unsaved changes will be lost" Even if one selects "Saty on page", the logout event proceeds and the narrative "looks" as before, but ...
- it should not be even visible if the user is logged out (close window, redirect, refresh, anything)
- not just narrative, but menu buttons stay there and initiall "work", but will not actually do what you want them to. E.g. share just hangs; kernel menu still works even without auth

if try to save "Narrative savew failed!" with no message, and just OK button; also hyellow message in narrative shows "You do not have permission to view the narrative with id XXX".

login works, and back to normal.

possible to have jupyter keyboard commands leak through in this case - fresh narrative view, make changes, logout out, click stay on page, try to log back in again -- now keystrokes go to ipython and start doing dark magic to one's narrative, and do not appear in the log in form.



## Markdown
- ~~Markdown cell state gets messed up (input AND output) upon going into edit mode.~~
- ~~double clicking should open up and put into edit mode. right now just puts into edit mode without opening, weird...~~
  - _so now it toggles open if it was closed to start with, does nothing additional with edit mode._
  - _next is to hide the output when going into edit mode. my guess is that the toggling gets reversed with the open/close, and the logic for the editor is to simply toggle the output area -- there is not input/output state stored in cell?_
  - _okay, that is now fixed. It was due to the jquery hide()/show() -- show ends up leaving display="block" on the element, even if it was not set originally. The new method adds display="none" and then removes the display style for showing. Also key to this is the method used by the markdown editor to swap the editor and rendered -- it uses a class on the cell (rendered/unrendered) to control the visilibity of the editor/rendered_
  
- exiting from edit mode is annoying. 
  - When blurring on the markdown edit field, it just closes. This makes sense when clicking to another narrative element (perhaps), but not when just blurring out to another app. If one is writing, and needs to activate other windows, etc. as part of that process, it is plain annoying to have the editor close down, lose cursor position, etc.
  
## Code Cells

- when opening a code cell, the widget area prompt is displayed. This is surely another case of the toggle method employed either being too crude or simply out of sync with the way that the notebook hides/shows code cell elements

## Concurrent Usage

There needs to be a better story for concurrent usage of a narrative. As it is, concurrent saves are allowed, and they do not "overwrite" but just will interleave changes in the versions; it does "appear" that there has been overwriting...
So, perhaps better detection of  # Nice to Have

- nicer save / savepoint feedback
- silly hover paragraph icon for markdown cells -- built into notebook, but why? 
- double click expands closed cells,
- remove extraneous items from kernel menu
- "About this Narrative" button/menu item and pop up dialog (or maybe even a cell?) populated with useful info about the narrative - created, last saved, versions, copies...
- narrative preferences: autosave, mode (basic/advanced), 
- run button in cell toolbar for code, app, method cells.
- help! we need more integrated help. For starters:
  - cell specific help - markdown, code cells
  - data cells should at least have (some of the) tools available in the data panel
  - app and method cells could open up a modal narrative method store
- better messaging experience -
   - consistent location for messages
   - better language
   - longer persistence, or long persistence with ability to close
   - message log (at least for the narrative session) with ability to clear, or expand to get more info or help.
   - this could be on the expanded left nav area
- "reset" or "normalize" for app/method cells. The jupyter markdown styling can interfere with widget styling, which causes otherwise good people to put in place hacks to override. (kb output cell something or other). Rather, the style reset should be at the top level, and any specific styling (for input, output, etc) within an app/method cell should be provided by the widget developer (or perhaps even there the app/method cell should provide this...) # Cool!

- drag and drop cells
- drag and drop apps and methods
- binding of cells to each other (move, d&d, delete, etc.)
- drag and drop code cell and markdown cell 
- basic and advanced mode. Advanced mode would unlock features like code cell icon, kernel menu, and perhaps other ipython stuff
- more metrics: narrative opens, narrative runs, ... # Ideas / Maybe

Move Apps and Methods into own panel, remove Narratives, make a better dashboard, or a slide out panel for narratives. Narratives is not really a useul tool to have within a narrative, compared to the primary tools of the object browser, app & method browser, and jobs. Also, the narrative browser should have more space -- titles often wrap, there should be search.

Move New Narrative to the horizontal menu (does not exist yet) or simply make a navbar button (for copy too)

Remove the annoying circle buttons at the bottom of the narrative. It is weird to have that be the way to add code and markdown cells, yet data viewers and apps/methods are added from the left side.

Remove the big + circle button from data. It is confusing, since there is already a way to pull up the data panel, and gets in the way.

While on the subject of the left area, perhaps there is a better way to provide "tabs". The horizontal space is very limited, and it may that there are more than major functions to expose. 

For example, what about a narrative summary (like or perhaps instead of an info pop-up), or a list of narrative elements with basic information and for navigation, and perhaps simple editing (move, delete cells). Could be useful for long narratives.

Insert raw images into narrative

data.markdown: KBase Data APIs === The Data API is an access layer for both reference and user data in KBase. * API documentation * GitHub repository README There are currently three high level KBase APIs for specific data types: * The GenomeAnnotation API provides methods to retrieve data from genome annotations in KBase. * The Assembly API provides methods to retrieve data for genome assemblies in KBase. * The Taxon API provides methods to retrieve data for taxa in KBase. Data objects can also be accessed through a generic object API. Future KBase development efforts will be targeting additional data types. Setting up the Data API ---- Example of using a KBase Data API: retrieving all proteins from a GenomeAnnotation ---- Example of using a KBase Data API: retrieving all contig ids for an Assembly ---- Example of using a KBase Data API: retrieving taxonomic id and scientific lineage for a Taxon ---- KBase Data API example narratives --- * Simple, complete example narrative using a KBase Data API client * A narrative with more examples of using a KBase Data API client * Quality plots for genome sequence data * GenomeAnnotation object comparison table * Simple example narrative using a KBase Data API library link to upload, how do I access data for my own genome
data.title: KBase Data API master index

data.markdown: ![KBase Logo](/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/kbase-logo-web.png) Welcome to the Narrative Interface! === What's a Narrative? --- Design and carry out collaborative computational experiments while creating Narratives: interactive, shareable, and reproducible records of your data, computational steps, and thought processes. learn more... Get Some Data --- Click the Add Data button in the Data Panel to browse for KBase data or upload your own. Mouse over a data object to add it to your Narrative, and check out more details once the data appears in your list. learn more... Analyze It --- Browse available analyses that can be run using KBase apps or methods (apps are just multi-step methods that make some common analyses more convenient). Select an analysis, fill in the fields, and click Run. Output will be generated, and new data objects will be created and added to your data list. Add to your results by running follow-on apps or methods. learn more... Save and Share Your Narrative --- Be sure to save your Narrative frequently. When you're ready, click the share button above to let collaborators view your analysis steps and results. Or better yet, make your Narrative public and help expand the social web that KBase is building to make systems biology research open, collaborative, and more effective. learn more... Find Documentation and Help --- For more information, please see the Narrative Interface User Guide or the app/method tutorials. Questions? Contact us! Ready to begin adding to your Narrative? You can keep this Welcome cell or delete it with the trash icon in the top right corner.

data.markdown:
# Repos required for kbase-ui:

## Overview

These are the repos currently used by kbase-ui

### The KBase UI web app
- kbase-ui
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-ui
    - collaborators: erik, bill

### AMD Packages
AMD packages are collections of AMD modules. They are packaged into namespaced directories with a structure like:
```
kb/PACKAGE/MODULE
```
This allows them to be integrated into the kbase-ui module tree without any special configuration. They are loaded by the module string "kb/PACKAGE/MODULE". E.g. *kb/common/html* loads the html utility module.

Each repo, which I refer to as a package, is given a verbose name, prefixed with *kbase-*. This is because they are each registered in the *Bower* and sometimes *NPM* registries. This is required in order to use semver-capable tools for specifying dependencies. In each case, the name registered with the service is also the repo name. Even though this may not be strictly necessary, it is much easier to manage them if the names are the same. Since the names are global, the *kbase-* prefix should make for unique package names. (This is debatable, since there is a kbase product which has been around for much longer that KBase has, although they don't appear to be in the Javscript business.)

- kbase-common-js
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-common-js
    - kbase org repo: exists (need to replace)
    - utility modules and subsystems which are or can be shared across javascript projects
- kbase-service-clients-js
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-service-clients-js
    - kbase org repo: need
    - clients for kbase services, bundled modules of such, and utility classes.
    - updated by hand when there are service client updates.
    - client updates are wrapped in js "promises" for easier and uniform codig in the ui or other apps
- kbase-ui-widget
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-widget
    - kbase org repo: need
    - widget base objects, widget managers, and legacy widget bases
- kbase-data-api-client-js
     - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-data-api-client-js
     - the data api thrift client wrappers; also includes all of the thrift dependencies
- kbase-data-thrift-clients
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-data-thrift-clients
    - the clients generated by the data api thrift project (all languages)
- kbase-data-thrift-js
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-data-thrift-js
    - thrift javascript support, provides binary protocol, xhr transport

### KBase UI Plugins
All widgets in kbase-ui are loaded via *plugins*. A plugin is a collection of configuration, javascript, and resources contained under a single directory and utilizing a specific directory structure and file naming convention. Widgets can provide modules, widgets, type mapping to widgets, routes, and menu items (which do not automatically appear, but are available for the ui.)

Many widgets are built into kbase ui. E.g. the layout, menu, login widget, login panel, user profile. However, larger widgets, those which are anticipated to be candidates for wholesale replacement, and those which may be utilized in more than one app (e.g. Narrative) are contained in separate plugin repos. A plugin repo is not much more than the plugin itself, although importantly they contain a bower.json configuration file required for installation.

Ideally they each will contain a test suite which can be run independently of kbase-ui, and can be developed in an isolated widget development tool, but at the moment the development process requires that they be loaded and iterated over within a local copy of kbase-ui.

It should be noted that a plugin can contain any arbitrary javascript code. Some of it may be loaded only within the local modules (e.g. utilities or special libraries), but there is a mechanism for making the code available globally with the host app. Widgets themselves are loaded into a special widget manager, although the code itself is technically provided as an AMD module.

- kbase-ui-plugin-vis-widgets
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-vis-widgets
    - kbase org repo: need
    - provides: widgets
    - Jim's vis widgets; other than demo pages, I don't think these are in actual use in the ui, although there are widgets in Narrative which use them.
- kbase-ui-plugin-typeview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-typeview
    - kbase org repo: need
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - Widgets supporting the viewing of types 
- kbase-ui-plugin-dataview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-dataview
    - kbase org repo: exists (need to replace)
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - Widgets supporting the "landing page", called dataview within the app, and the original set of data viewing widgets. 
- kbase-ui-plugin-dashboard
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-dashboard
    - kbase org repo: exists (need to replace)
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widgets
    - The main dashboard view in kbase-ui. A separate repo due to size, complexity, and the fact that it probably (or at least should) be refactored. It is trivial to swap out one plugin for a replacement one, so refactoring plugins is one of the main use cases.
- kbase-ui-plugin-datawidgets
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-datawidgets.git
    - kbaes org repo: need
    - provides: widgets
    - This was a seminal effort at refactoring dataview widgets. Just a few were ported over. They work, but are in various states of exploration for widget api ideas. 
- kbase-ui-plugin-methodview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-methodview.git
    - kbase org repo: need
    - provides: route, panel, widgets
    - For viewing method "man pages" for legacy methods. At present it passes through methods to the appcatalog, and shows a view for apps.
- kbase-ui-plugin-data-landing-pages
    - https://github.com/kbase/kbase-ui-plugin-data-landing-pages
    - provides: widgets
    - new data view widgets created for the data api. This is brand new and actively developed by the data api team.

### Development Plugins
There is a collection of plugins supplying tools useful for development. It is also a model for how developers can utlize their own development plugins in order to provide system exploration, introspection, prototyping, etc.

I don't know if any of these need to litter the kbase repo space. Perhaps there is a kbase developer repo that would be more suitable?

- kbase-ui-plugin-typeview
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-typeview.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - A simple datatable-based view of all types registered in the current workspace deployment (depends on the kbase-ui build). This is very useful for testing typeview. In addition, each type-row has a browse link which brings up a dataview with the type filtered.
- kbase-ui-plugin-dataview    
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-dataview.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - A simple datatable-based presentation of all objects the current user has access to. Very useful in combination with the typeview, as it takes a type parameter for filtering (and will query workspace with this type). Each object-row has a link to typeview for the type and dataview for the object. This is a critical tool for dataview testing.
- kbase-ui-plugin-jobbrowser
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-jobbrowser.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget
    - A simple table of all jobs accessible to the current user as reported by the UJS service for the current deployment environment. It was put together to assist in debugging the dataview downloader, to be able to monitor the status transform jobs.
- kbase-ui-plugin-shockbrowser
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-shockbrowser.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget    
    - A simple table view of all files reported by the shock client. Also developed for debugging of the dataview download tool
- kbase-ui-plugin-data-api-demo
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-data-api-demo.git
    - provides: menu item, route, panel, widget    
    - This widget lists all accessible data objects for types compatible with the data api. Each found object provides a link, which invokes a simple table rendering of all known methods/properties of an api call relevant to the given object. Useful for debugging the data api, and esp. for inspecting a variety of objects of different types and versions.
- kbase-ui-plugin-demo-vis-widget
    - https://github.com/eapearson/kbase-ui-plugin-demo-vis-widget.git
    - provides: menu items, routes, panels, widgets     
    - Useful for esting several of Jim's vis widgets. Good for testing that these widgets haven't been broken; should be expanded to cover all widgets; in the future should be updated to reflect standardized types accepted by the widgets, and also to serve as automated ui testing endpoints.

data.markdown: ![KBase Logo](/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/kbase-logo-web.png) Welcome to the Narrative Interface! === What's a Narrative? --- Design and carry out collaborative computational experiments while creating Narratives: interactive, shareable, and reproducible records of your data, computational steps, and thought processes. learn more... Get Some Data --- Click the Add Data button in the Data Panel to browse for KBase data or upload your own. Mouse over a data object to add it to your Narrative, and check out more details once the data appears in your list. learn more... Analyze It --- Browse available analyses that can be run using KBase apps or methods (apps are just multi-step methods that make some common analyses more convenient). Select an analysis, fill in the fields, and click Run. Output will be generated, and new data objects will be created and added to your data list. Add to your results by running follow-on apps or methods. learn more... Save and Share Your Narrative --- Be sure to save your Narrative frequently. When you're ready, click the share button above to let collaborators view your analysis steps and results. Or better yet, make your Narrative public and help expand the social web that KBase is building to make systems biology research open, collaborative, and more effective. learn more... Find Documentation and Help --- For more information, please see the Narrative Interface User Guide or the app/method tutorials. Questions? Contact us! Ready to begin adding to your Narrative? You can keep this Welcome cell or delete it with the trash icon in the top right corner.
